ai-dn10:1.1.2_0: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. It was not long after the Buddha had become fully extinguished.
ai-dn10:1.1.3_0: Now at that time the brahmin student Subha, Todeyya’s son, was residing in Sāvatthī on some business.
ai-dn10:1.2.1_0: Then he addressed a certain student,
ai-dn10:1.2.2_0: “Go, student, and approach the ascetic Ānanda
ai-dn10:1.2.2_1: and after approaching I ask Ānanda, ascetic Ānanda, in good health, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-dn10:1.2.3_0: whether he’s healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-dn10:1.3.1_0: ‘Sir, please visit the student Subha, Todeyya’s son, at his home out of compassion.’”
ai-dn10:1.3.2_0: “Yes, sir,” replied the student, and did as he was asked.
ai-dn10:1.3.2_1: and after approaching he exchanged greetings with venerable Ānanda,
ai-dn10:1.3.3_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-dn10:1.3.6_0: ‘Sir, please visit the student Subha, Todeyya’s son, at his home out of compassion.’”
ai-dn10:1.4.1_0: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to him,
ai-dn10:1.4.3_0: I’ve drunk sufficient refreshments for today.
ai-dn10:1.4.4_0: But hopefully tomorrow I’ll get a chance to visit him.”
ai-dn10:1.4.5_0: “Yes, sir,” replied the student. He went back to Subha, and told him what had happened.
ai-dn10:1.4.5_1: and after approaching he said this to the student Subha:
ai-dn10:1.4.7_0: ‘He would, though I was healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-dn10:1.4.8_0: “Sir, please visit the student Subha, Todeyya’s son, at his home out of compassion.”
ai-dn10:1.4.9_0: When I had spoken, Ānanda said to me:
ai-dn10:1.4.11_0: I’ve drunk sufficient refreshments for today.
ai-dn10:1.4.12_0: But hopefully tomorrow I’ll get a chance to visit him.’
ai-dn10:1.4.13_0: “This much, sir, I managed to do. At least Master Ānanda will take the opportunity to visit tomorrow.”
ai-dn10:1.5.1_0: Then when the night had passed, Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went with Venerable Cetaka as his second monk to Subha’s home.
ai-dn10:1.5.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-dn10:1.5.1_2: Then Subha the student went to Venerable Ānanda,
ai-dn10:1.5.1_3: and after approaching he exchanged greetings with venerable Ānanda,
ai-dn10:1.5.2_0: and after exchanging courteous talk and greetings, he sat down on one side.
ai-dn10:1.5.2_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Ānanda:
ai-dn10:1.5.3_0: “Master Ānanda, you were Master Gotama’s attendant. You were close to him, living in his presence.
ai-dn10:1.5.4_0: ‘I would know this, Ānanda, and that the Buddha praised.’
ai-dn10:1.5.5_1: And where do you encourage someone to become established?”
ai-dn10:1.6.1_0: “Student, the Buddha praises three sets of things.
ai-dn10:1.6.1_1: And there he encouraged those people to encourage him.
ai-dn10:1.6.3_0: The entire spectrum of noble ethics, immersion, and wisdom.
ai-dn10:1.6.4_0: These are the three sets of things that the Buddha praises.
ai-dn10:1.6.4_1: Well established this people in the home you sure.”
ai-dn10:1.6.6_0: But what, Master Ānanda, was that noble spectrum of ethics that the Buddha praised?”
ai-dn10:1.7.1_0: “Consider when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
ai-dn10:1.7.2_0: He realizes with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
ai-dn10:1.7.3_0: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
ai-dn10:1.8.1_0: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some good family.
ai-dn10:1.8.2_0: After hearing that teaching they gain faith.
ai-dn10:1.8.4_0: ‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.
ai-dn10:1.8.5_0: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ai-dn10:1.8.6_0: Why don’t I go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
ai-dn10:1.9.1_0: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-dn10:1.10.1_0: Once they’ve gone forth, they live restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.
ai-dn10:1.11.1_0: And how is a mendicant accomplished in ethics?
ai-dn10:1.11.2_0: It’s when a mendicant gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings. ...
ai-dn10:1.11.3_0: When a mendicant gives up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings. ...
ai-dn10:1.28.1_0: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by unworthy branches of knowledge, by wrong livelihood. ...
ai-dn10:1.28.2_0: This includes rites for propitiation, for granting wishes, for ghosts, for the earth, for rain, for property settlement, and for preparing and consecrating house sites, and rites involving rinsing and bathing, and oblations. It also includes administering emetics, purgatives, expectorants, and phlegmagogues; administering ear-oils, eye restoratives, nasal medicine, ointments, and counter-ointments; surgery with needle and scalpel, treating children, pres, pres, and binding on herbs.
ai-dn10:1.28.3_0: They refrain from such unworthy branches of knowledge, such wrong livelihood. ...
ai-dn10:1.28.4_0: Since those ascetics and brahmins eat food given in faith,
ai-dn10:1.28.5_0: This includes rites for propitiation, for the sake of defecating, and for the one who looks for support.
ai-dn10:1.28.6_0: They refrain from such unworthy branches of knowledge, such wrong livelihood. ...
ai-dn10:1.29.1_0: A mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
ai-dn10:1.29.2_0: It’s like a king who has defeated his enemies. He sees no danger from his foes in any quarter.
ai-dn10:1.29.3_0: A mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
ai-dn10:1.29.4_0: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
ai-dn10:1.29.5_0: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics.
ai-dn10:1.30.1_0: This is that noble spectrum of ethics that the Buddha praised.
ai-dn10:1.30.2_0: But there is still more to be done.”
ai-dn10:1.30.4_0: This noble spectrum of ethics is complete, not lacking anything!
ai-dn10:1.30.5_0: Such a complete spectrum of ethics cannot be seen among the other ascetics and brahmins.
ai-dn10:1.30.6_0: Were other ascetics and brahmins to see such a complete spectrum of ethics in themselves, they’d be delighted with just that much:
ai-dn10:1.30.7_0: ‘At this point it’s enough; at this point our work is done. We’ve reached the goal of our ascetic life. There is nothing more to be done.’
ai-dn10:1.30.9_0: ‘But there is still more to be done.’
ai-dn10:2.1.1_0: But what, Master Ānanda, was that noble spectrum of immersion that the Buddha praised?”
ai-dn10:2.2.1_0: “And how, student, does a mendicant guard the sense doors?
ai-dn10:2.2.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-dn10:2.2.3_0: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
ai-dn10:2.2.3_1: They practice restraint, protect the faculty of sight, and achieve its restraint.
ai-dn10:2.2.4_0: When you hear a sound with your ears ...
ai-dn10:2.2.5_0: When they smell an odor with their nose ...
ai-dn10:2.2.6_0: Tasting a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-dn10:2.2.7_0: Feeling a touch with the body ...
ai-dn10:2.2.8_0: Knowing a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-dn10:2.2.9_0: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
ai-dn10:2.2.9_1: They practice restraint, protect the faculty of mind, and achieve its restraint.
ai-dn10:2.2.10_0: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
ai-dn10:2.2.11_0: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.
ai-dn10:2.3.1_0: And how does a mendicant have mindfulness and situational awareness?
ai-dn10:2.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
ai-dn10:2.3.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has mindfulness and situational awareness.
ai-dn10:2.4.1_0: And how is a mendicant content?
ai-dn10:2.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and alms-food to look after the belly.
ai-dn10:2.4.2_1: Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
ai-dn10:2.4.3_0: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
ai-dn10:2.4.4_0: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and alms-food to look after the belly.
ai-dn10:2.4.4_1: Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
ai-dn10:2.4.5_0: That’s how a mendicant is content.
ai-dn10:2.5.1_0: When they have this noble spectrum of ethics, this noble sense restraint, this noble mindfulness and situational awareness, and this noble contentment,
ai-dn10:2.5.2_0: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
ai-dn10:2.5.3_0: After the meal, they return from alms-round, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there.
ai-dn10:2.6.1_0: Giving up desire for the world, he meditates with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire.
ai-dn10:2.6.2_0: Giving up ill will, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will and malevolence.
ai-dn10:2.6.3_0: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
ai-dn10:2.6.4_0: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
ai-dn10:2.6.5_0: Giving up doubt, he meditates having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.

ai-dn10:2.12.1_0: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.
ai-dn10:2.12.2_0: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and sanctuary.

ai-dn10:2.12.4_0: Seeing that the hindrances have been given up in them, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed.
ai-dn10:2.13.1_0: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption ...
ai-dn10:2.13.2_0: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.

ai-dn10:2.14.1_1: They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
ai-dn10:2.14.2_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.

ai-dn10:2.15.2_0: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.

ai-dn10:2.16.1_1: There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and no rainfall to replenish it from time to time.

ai-dn10:2.26.1_0: Suppose an expert potter or their apprentice had some well-prepared clay. They could produce any kind of pot that they like.
ai-dn10:2.26.2_0: Or suppose an expert ivory-carver or their apprentice had some well-prepared ivory. They could produce any kind of ivory item that they like.
ai-dn10:2.26.3_0: Or suppose an expert goldsmith or their apprentice had some well-prepared gold. They could produce any kind of gold item that they like.
ai-dn10:2.26.4_0: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-dn10:2.26.4_1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward psychic power.
ai-dn10:2.26.5_0: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again ...
ai-dn10:2.26.5_1: he exercises power as far as the Brahma worlds with his body.
ai-dn10:2.27.1_0: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward clairaudience.
ai-dn10:2.27.2_0: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.
ai-dn10:2.27.3_0: Suppose there was a person traveling along the road.
ai-dn10:2.27.3_1: They’d hear the sound of drums, clay drums, horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms.
ai-dn10:2.27.3_2: They’d think: ‘That’s the sound of drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of clay-drums,’ and ‘that’s the sound of horns, kettledrums, and tom-toms.’
ai-dn10:2.27.4_0: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-dn10:2.27.5_0: When their mind is immersed in samādhi like this,
ai-dn10:2.27.5_1: They extend and project the mind toward clairaudience.
ai-dn10:2.27.6_0: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and divine, whether near or far.
ai-dn10:2.28.1_0: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward comprehending the minds of others.
ai-dn10:2.28.3_0: mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,
ai-dn10:2.28.4_0: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed.’
ai-dn10:2.28.9_0: They know constricted mind as ‘constricted mind,’
ai-dn10:2.28.15_0: mind immersed in samādhi as ‘mind immersed in samādhi,’
ai-dn10:2.28.16_0: and mind not immersed in samādhi as ‘mind not immersed in samādhi.’
ai-dn10:2.28.18_0: They understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.
ai-dn10:2.29.1_0: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they had a spot they’d know ‘I have a spot,’ and if they had no spots they’d know ‘I have no spots.’
ai-dn10:2.29.2_0: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-dn10:2.29.3_0: When their mind is immersed in samādhi like this,
ai-dn10:2.29.3_1: They extend and project the mind toward the imperturbable.
ai-dn10:2.29.5_0: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’ ...
ai-dn10:2.30.1_0: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward recollection of past lives.
ai-dn10:2.30.2_0: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding.
ai-dn10:2.30.2_2: ʻThere I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
ai-dn10:2.30.2_3: passing away from there I arose in another state of existence,
ai-dn10:2.30.2_4: and there I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
ai-dn10:2.30.2_5: When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else.
ai-dn10:2.30.2_6: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-dn10:2.31.1_0: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village.
ai-dn10:2.31.1_2: From that village they’d go to yet another village.
ai-dn10:2.31.1_4: ‘I went from my home village to another village.
ai-dn10:2.31.1_5: There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that.
ai-dn10:2.31.1_6: Having come down from that village they’ve returned to their own village.’
ai-dn10:2.31.2_0: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-dn10:2.31.2_1: When their mind is immersed in samādhi like this,
ai-dn10:2.31.2_2: They extend it and project the mind toward knowledge of the imperturbable.
ai-dn10:2.31.3_0: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding.
ai-dn10:2.31.3_2: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-dn10:2.32.1_0: When their mind is immersed like this,
ai-dn10:2.32.1_1: They extend and project the mind toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
ai-dn10:2.32.2_0: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-dn10:2.32.2_1: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-dn10:2.32.2_2: They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view.
ai-dn10:2.32.2_3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
ai-dn10:2.32.2_4: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’
ai-dn10:2.32.2_5: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
ai-dn10:2.33.1_0: Suppose there was a stilt longhouse at the central square.
ai-dn10:2.33.1_2: ‘These are people entering and leaving a house, walking along the streets and paths, and sitting at the central square.’
ai-dn10:2.33.2_0: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-dn10:2.33.3_0: When their mind is immersed in samādhi like this,
ai-dn10:2.33.3_1: They extend and project the mind toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
ai-dn10:2.33.4_0: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-dn10:2.34.1_0: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-dn10:2.34.2_0: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-dn10:2.34.3_0: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ ... ‘This is the origin of defilements’ ... ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
ai-dn10:2.35.1_0: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
ai-dn10:2.35.2_0: When it is freed, he knows it is freed.
ai-dn10:2.35.3_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-dn10:2.36.1_0: Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with good eyesight standing on the bank would see the mussel shells, gravel and pebbles, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.
ai-dn10:2.36.1_1: A person with good eyesight standing on the bank would see the mussel shells, gravel and pebbles, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.
ai-dn10:2.36.1_3: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded.
ai-dn10:2.36.1_4: And here are the mussel shells, gravel and pebbles, and schools of fish swimmming about or staying still.’
ai-dn10:2.36.2_0: In the same way, when their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it and project it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-dn10:2.36.3_0: When their mind is immersed in samādhi like this,
ai-dn10:2.36.3_1: They extend and project the mind toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
ai-dn10:2.36.4_0: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-dn10:2.36.5_0: They truly understand the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.
ai-dn10:2.36.6_0: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
ai-dn10:2.37.1_0: This is that noble spectrum of wisdom that the Buddha praised.
ai-dn10:2.37.2_0: And there is nothing more to be done.”
ai-dn10:2.37.4_0: This noble spectrum of wisdom is complete, not lacking anything!
ai-dn10:2.37.5_0: Such a complete spectrum of wisdom cannot be seen among the other ascetics and brahmins.
ai-dn10:2.37.6_0: And there is nothing more to be done.
ai-dn10:2.37.8_0: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
ai-dn10:2.37.8_1: so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-dn10:2.37.8_2: just so have you made the Teaching clear in many ways.
ai-dn10:2.37.9_0: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-dn10:2.37.10_0: From this day forth, may Master Ānanda remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-dn10:2.37.11_0: The tenth section on Subha is finished.
